abstract: In April 2007, Piton de la Fournaise volcano experienced its largest caldera collapse in at least 300 yr. This event consisted of a series of 48 subsidence increments characterized by very-long-period (VLP) seismic signals equivalent to Mw 4.4 to 5.4. Source analysis of VLP events suggests a piston-like mechanism with a collapsing crack source corresponding to the contraction of the magma reservoir and a single force representing the collapse of the above rock column. We show that the collapse dynamics is primarily controlled by magma withdrawal from the reservoir, which was likely in a bubbly state at the time of the event. Similar to the 2018 Kilauea collapse, we observe a reduction of the time-interval between successive subsidence increments, which results from the acceleration of magma withdrawal and a progressive weakening of the edifice at the beginning of the sequence.

author_highlights.sentence: We investigate the source mechanism of the 2007 Piton de la Fournaise summit collapse.
Our analys is suggests a collapsing crack source and an initially upwards verticalforce.
This suggests a piston source in which a collapsing column moves in the magma chamber.
Collapse dynamics are primarily controlled by magma outflow from the reservoir.
Observations also suggest a weakening of the edifice at the beginning of the collapse.

body_text.sentence: As mentioned above, the April 2007 collapse can possibly involve different source processes that can be modeled at long period by a moment tensor source (e.g., slip on a ring fault, contraction of a magma reservoir) or by a single force (e.g., unloading and loading of the volcanic edifice by the detaching rock column).
body_text.title: Source mechanism of the main collapse event on April 5, 2007

parents.title: Source mechanism of the main collapse event on April 5, 2007

body_text.sentence: However, this delay remains small compared to the sampling rate of the seismological data (1 sample per second).
body_text.title: Joint inversion of moment tensor and force

body_text.sentence: As mentioned above, the surface collapse activity was preceded by a series of VLP precursors visible in Fig. 7.
body_text.title: Discussion and conclusion

body_text.sentence: Although numerous collapses have occurred in the summit area since the 18th century, the 2007 event is the largest collapse reported at Piton de la Fournaise (Michon et al., 2013).
body_text.title: Introduction

parents.title: Source mechanism of the main collapse event on April 5, 2007

body_text.sentence: We also conduct a joint inversion of moment tensor and force parameters.
body_text.title: Joint inversion of moment tensor and force

body_text.sentence: While magma outflow from a sub-surface reservoir is usually associated with summit deflations (e.g., Epp et al., 1983), collapses can also act as a mechanism to push the magma out of the chamber.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: This interpretation seems consistent with our joint source models showing that the closing crack source usually occurs before the vertical force is applied to the edifice (cf., Fig. 4 and Table S6).
body_text.title: Discussion and conclusion

parents.title: Source mechanism of the main collapse event on April 5, 2007

body_text.sentence: At long period, the effect of a detached mass can be modeled by a single time-varying force (e.g., Kanamori and Given, 1982; Ekström and Stark, 2013).
body_text.title: Single force inversion
